source.raw_text:
The Bird-Dog exercise targets the deep core (transverse abdominis, obliques, rectus abdominis), spinal extensors (erector spinae), glutes, hamstrings, and upper back/shoulders (traps, deltoids, lats) for spinal stability, balance, and coordination, working by extending the opposite arm and leg from a quadruped (all-fours) position to build functional strength and improve posture. The movement pattern involves slow, controlled anti-rotation and extension, emphasizing neutral spine and resisting hip/shoulder shifting. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7]  
Muscles Worked 

• Core: Transverse Abdominis, Rectus Abdominis, Obliques (for stability). 
• Back: Erector Spinae (along the spine), Trapezius, Latissimus Dorsi (upper back). 
• Glutes: Gluteus Maximus, Medius, Minimus (buttock muscles). 
• Shoulders: Deltoids (front), Pectoralis (chest) (stabilizers). 
• Legs: Hamstrings (back of thigh). [3, 4, 6, 8, 9]  

Movement Pattern (Functional Movement) 

• Starting Position: All fours (hands under shoulders, knees under hips). 
• Action: Extend one arm forward and the opposite leg straight back, keeping them in line with the torso. 
• Key Focus: Maintain a neutral spine (avoid arching or rounding), keep hips and shoulders level, and reach long through fingertips and toes. 
• Return: Slowly return to the start and alternate sides. 
• Pattern Type: An anti-rotation, contralateral (opposite limbs) movement that promotes spinal stability and functional core strength for daily tasks and sports. [1, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 10]
